awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Scalable MIMO Spatial Filtering and Synchronization for Heterogenous Wireless Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Wireless networks are an integral part of the information infrastructure and are more widespread than even access to electricity in some parts of the world. The primary challenge for next-generation wireless networks is data capacity. Wireless data usage is doubling every year and network providers are projecting demand approaching one gigabit per user per day. This requires a 1000x increase in network capacity and 100x increase in worst-case data rates. Since availability of spectrum is limited, the higher capacity must be achieved by sharing existing spectrum among users and improving the performance of wireless systems. However, mobile applications also require low power consumption for longer battery life.  This project will investigate energy-efficient wireless circuits and systems for next-generation wireless networks that can provide gigabit per second links while operating under dense spectrum reuse. Developing such wireless systems has broad impact since improving the availability and speed of wireless links will expand existing applications as well as enable new applications that benefit economy and society. Synergy between education and research includes the creation of an inter-disciplinary course on multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) communications. This will allow students to identify and solve high-impact cross-domain problems in wireless networks. Outreach to high school students will create opportunities for early exposure to research environments, strengthening STEM pipelines.

Next-generation wireless networks will be based on MIMO systems for increased capacity in the context of spectrum scarcity and extreme densification. This project investigates MIMO circuits and architectures to achieve interference cancellation and enable next-generation, high-capacity wireless networks. The increasing speed of CMOS transistors and near-zero incremental cost of additional transistors allow the development of novel integrated architectures that leverage multiple transmit-receive elements to achieve higher performance and interferer tolerance. Ensuring the scalability of such architectures in terms of energy-efficiency and performance is critical as next-generation networks transition to larger number of elements and higher performance. This project will also study circuits and architectures for simplifying synchronization between elements in large-scale MIMO arrays. Using multiple elements to improve transceiver frontend performance results in relaxed analog-to-digital converter requirements, thereby enabling digital-intensive architectures that further support scalability.

por.por_cntn:
The fundamental challenge for next-generation wireless networks is data capacity. Wireless data usage is doubling every year and while the vision and technologies for such networks are still evolving, only 2-4x increase in available spectrum at microwave frequencies is expected in the coming years. Therefore, innovation in circuits and wireless systems is required for increased use of valuable spectrum. 

 

In this project, we've developed new architectures that allow wireless radios to operate in the presence of other radios or jammers that are using the same spectrum and creating interference. We demonstrated state-of-the-art performance with our architectures that are particularly well suited for MIMO networks. In particular, our architectures break the trade-offs between ability to tolerate jammers, the power consumed by the radio, and the minimum signal or the range achieved by the wireless link. These approaches are relevant to both low frequency spectrum that is conventionally used for wireless links as well for emerging mm-wave bands that promise even higher network capacity. 

 

Important results achieved during this project include the first demonstration of interferer-tolerant networks for MIMO wireless links and demonstration of wideband cancellation of interference from transmitter at RF and mm-wave radar. We first demonstrated a new receiver approach that increased the bandwidth of cancellation for RF transceivers.  In the case of MIMO, there are multiple sources of interference that have to be cancelled and in our follow-on work, we demonstrated the first approach to cancel MIMO cross talk. As shown in Fig. 1, we demonstrated this cancellation in a practical implementation showing the feasibility of our approach for commercial deployment. Finally, in our most recent work, we demonstrated architectures that extended cancellation to mm-wave frequencies. 

 

In addition to challenges associated with increasing capacity in wireless networks, enabling long battery lifetimes for sensor radios is important. Traditionally, lower power consumption comes at the cost of using the same radio in different countries which have differences in frequency allocations. As shown in Fig. 2, we have developed an architecture for low-power radios that are able to operation with low power consumption while also being suitable for deployment in different geographies. Importantly, our approach allows many radios to operate at the same time since the architecture developed ensures tolerance to other radios transmitting and receiving at frequencies close to the radio frequency. 

We are building upon our research in this project to develop low-power interferer tolerant radios for sensors and to improve performance of automotive radar, enabling better detection of objects using radar sensors.
